title: Finn Mayhew
text:
Other places
I have other music on SoundCloud and at this YouTube playlist.

title: Finn Mayhew
text:
IceCube

Photo credit: Emanuel Jacobi, IceCube/NSF
For my PhD at Michigan State University, I’m working with MSU’s IceCube group under Dr. Tyce DeYoung.
IceCube is both a telescope and a detector. As a telescope, it uses elementary particles called neutrinos to see very high-energy happenings very far away. As a detector, it allows the collaboration to study the fundamental properties of neutrinos themselves.
My work with IceCube aims to look for non-standard neutrino interactions (NSI) through the experiment’s oscillations measurements, which look at neutrinos that originate in the atmosphere and travel thr ough the Earth to the detector at the South Pole. NSI is a beyond-the-standard-model-of-particle-physics (BSM) effect that is predicted by several hypotheses of the origin of neutrino mass. Below is a graphic that outlines the analysis procedure.


Learn more about IceCube in general
Wander through the notes that I’m taking to understand NSI
Watch my first guidance committee meeting talk, where I presented my research up to the point of joining the OscNext NSI team
Play with a neutrino oscillation visualizer
Look at 10 years of up-going muon neutrinos detected by IceCube

title: Finn Mayhew
text:
Laser-Induced Graphene Testing
As part of MSU’s TRAIN-MI high-energy physics detector instrumentation traineeship program, under Dr. Kendall Mahn I’m creating and testing the properties of laser-induced graphene (LIG) for potential use as a material for a field cage in a time projection chamber in space that would detect astrophysical gamma rays. Eventually we’ll collaborate with researchers at SLAC on this.

title: Finn Mayhew
text:
NOνA

Photo credit: Reidar Hahn, Fermilab Creative Services
As an undergrad at William & Mary, I worked with W&M’s NOνA group under Dr. Patricia Vahle.
NOνA is also a neutrino experiment, except instead of looking at neutrinos from space or Earth’s atmosphere, it produces its own neutrinos at an accelerator and shoots them through the Earth to a detector to study their fundamental properties.
My work helped with the calibration of the experiment’s far detector and test beam beamline instrumentation.
Learn more here.

title: Finn Mayhew
text:
My main channel is CosmosSurfer, though I rarely use it now.
My occasionally-active channel with my cousins is The FDA. Of note is our 11-year-long show The Lake Anna Adventure.
I once had a collab channel with my friend Kadian called BlueJacketPictures.
I also once had a Minecraft collab channel with my friends Murray and Brinn called Murbinfin.
When I was super young I uploaded videos to Spacetimejig.

title: Finn Mayhew
text:
Podcasts
I uploaded a D&D campaign I ran with my friend Chris called Galactic Gazette as a video podcast.
My friend Joe and I used to make a podcast about media we enjoy called Fools and Fiction.
